Electrocatalytic hydrodechlorination of 2,4-dichlorophenol on Pd catalysts supported on N-doped mesoporous carbons: Impact of electronic effects Tianyi Wu Data curation Methodology Investigation Writing – original draft a Yinjie Zuo Data curation Investigation a Huan Chen Supervision Writing – review & editing b Zhaoyi Xu Supervision Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ Shourong Zheng Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Pollution Control and Resource Reuse, School of the Environment, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, PR China State Key Laboratory of Pollution Control and Resource Reuse, School of the Environment, Nanjing University Nanjing 210023 PR China State Key Laboratory of Pollution Control and resource Reuse, School of the Environment, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210023, PR China b School of Environmental & Biological Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, PR China School of Environmental & Biological Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology Nanjing 210094 PR China School of Environmental & Biological Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The Pd catalysts supported on activated carbon (AC), ordered mesoporous carbon (CMK3) and N-doped mesoporous carbon (NCMK3) were prepared, and electrocatalytic hydrodechlorination (EHDC) of 2,4-dichlorophenol (2,4-DCP) was studied on the catalysts. The electronic properties of Pd particles in Pd/NCMK3 were modulated using varied reduction temperature. Increasing reduction temperature from 200 to 300 °C leads to the decrease of Pdn+/Pd0 in Pd/NCMK3 from 1.56 to 0.83. As a result, Pd/NCMK3 reduced at 200 °C exhibits substantially enhanced EHDC activity for 2,4-DCP with a peak mass activity of 3.37 min−1 mgPd −1, which is much better than previously reported catalysts. The DFT calculation shows that highly effective activation of C-Cl bonds can be achieved on cationic Pd species. Furthermore, the Pd/NCMK3 catalyst shows excellent electrocatalytic stability for EHDC of 2,4-DCP, demonstrating its great potential in the long-term application in the electrocatalytic removal of chlorinated pollutants. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Electrocatalytic dechlorination 2,4-dichlorophenol Supported Pd catalyst N-doped ordered mesoporous carbon Electronic effects Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Chlorophenols (CPs) are important chemical raw materials and intermediates, which are widely used in pesticide production, wood preservatives, herbicides, dyes and other organic products [1]. However, these substances feature high bioaccumulation, strong toxicity and carcinogenicity, posing a great threat to human health and the ecological system upon discharge into water environment [2]. As a result, CPs have been identified as priority pollutants by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) [3]. Therefore, it is highly appealing to develop efficient strategies to remove CPs in a cost-effective and eco-friendly fashion. Reductive dechlorination has been deemed as an effective avenue to detoxify chlorinated organic pollutants. Accordingly, numerous reductive methods have been explored, such as zero-valent Fe reduction [4–6], catalytic liquid phase hydrogenation [7], and photocatalytic reduction [8,9]. Among those methods, electrocatalytic hydrodechlorination (EHDC) is a very fascinating technology because of effective utilization of clean electric energy, which is competitive and environmentally friendly without secondary pollution [10,11]. Despite those merits, EHDC of CPs suffers from low reaction efficiency, impeding its wide application in practical environmental remediation [12]. In general, EHDC utilizes active hydrogen as the strong dechlorination species in reductive cleavage of C-Cl bonds of CPs on cathode surface [13,14], and Pd catalysts supported on carbonaceous materials are considered as the most effective cathode catalysts because of the very strong H2 activation capability of Pd particles and high conductivity of carbon supports [15,16]. The catalytic performances of Pd catalysts are closely correlated with the geometric and electronic properties of Pd particles. From the viewpoint of geometric effects, enhanced electrocatalytic activity was generally achieved on highly dispersed Pd based catalyst in electrochemical hydrodechlorination of CPs [17]. However, it should be emphasized that carbon supported Pd catalysts commonly have large Pd particles and low Pd dispersion due to the high hydrophobicity of carbon support and thus weak metal-support interaction, resulting in low catalytic activity and feasible catalyst deactivation owing to detachment of metal particles from carbon supports [18]. Doping carbonaceous materials with heteroatoms (i.e., O, N or S) can effectively modulate surface hydrophobicity of the support, leading to enhanced Pd dispersion [19]. Furthermore, rich mesopores render carbon supports unique confinement effects, giving rise to highly dispersed metal particles [20]. Alternatively, strong electronic effects of supported Pd catalysts are occasionally identified in liquid phase catalytic hydrogenation reactions. For example, Zhang et al. concluded that metallic Pd delivered higher turnover frequency (TOF) in bromate reduction due to its stronger H2 activation capability [21]. Alvarez-Montero et al. concluded that the coexistence of Pdn+ and Pd0 in Pd catalyst favored the effective catalytic hydrogenation of chloromethanes, and a high content of electro-deficient Pd resulted in enhanced catalytic activity [22]. However, the impact of electronic effects on the catalytic performances for electrocatalytic has been rarely discussed thus far [23]. In this work, we prepared Pd catalysts supported on N-doped porous carbon and investigated EHDC of 2,4-dichlorophenol on the catalysts. The Pd catalysts supported on AC and porous carbon (CMK3) were also prepared for comparison. To explore the impact of electronic effects, the Pdn+ contents of the catalysts were tuned via varying reduction temperature. The effects of Pdn+/Pd0 ratio on EHDC efficiency, reaction pathway and dechlorination mechanism were further studied. The crucial role of Pdn+ on the activation of 2,4-DCP and intermediates was verified by density functional theory (DFT). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and chemicals Materials and chemicals used in this work are presented in the Supporting Information. 2.2 Preparation of Pd electrocatalysts Palladium catalysts supported on different carbonaceous supports were prepared by the precipitation-deposition method with a nominal Pd loading amount of 2.0 wt%. Three supports with porous structure (i.e., AC, CMK3 or NCMK3) were used in this study and the details of the preparation of catalyst supports were described in the Supporting Information. For the preparation of supported Pd catalysts, 1.7 mL of PdCl2 (6 mg mL−1 Pd) solution and 0.5 g of supports were mixed with 50 mL water, which were stirred at room temperature for 3 h. The pH of the mixture solution was adjusted to 10.5 with 1 M Na2CO3. The resultant solid was filtrated, rinsed, dried overnight and calcined at 200 °C under N2 for 2 h. The materials were then reduced at 200 °C in a H2 flow of 25 mL min−1 for 2 h to obtain the reduced catalysts denoted as Pd/AC-200 and Pd/CMK3–200. The Pd/NCMK3 catalysts with varied Pd reduction levels were prepared by the same method, but at different reduction temperatures. The resultant catalyst was designated as Pd/NCMK3-X, where X is the reduction temperature. Notably, our preliminary experiments showed that very low H2 reduction temperature likely leads to the formation of instable Pd in the Pd/NCMK3 catalyst. Hence, the Pd/NCMK3 catalyst was prepared by reduction at 200 °C without using lower H2 reduction temperatures. To prepare the cathode, 20 mg of supported catalyst was dispersed in a solution consisting of 1200 μL DMF, 720 μL ethanol and 80 μL 5 wt% nafion solution. NF was used as the electrode carrier of the catalysts due to its excellent conductivity and low EHDC catalytic activity [24,25]. The mixture was sonicated for 30 min to form a uniform ink (10 mg mL−1) to ensure good distribution and deposition of catalyst on NF. Then, the catalyst ink (2 mL) was dropped on the pretreated NF electrode (contact area 2 cm × 5 cm, 1.5 mm thick) and dried at room temperature to obtain the working electrode. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were applied to determine Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas and pore structures of the samples. The samples were pretreated at 200 °C for 4 h under vacuum (1.33 Pa). The structures of the samples were measured using X-ray diffraction. The valence and surface content of palladium in the samples were determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. The contents of Pd in the catalysts were accurately determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES). The morphology of the working electrode was studied by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), and the composition of the catalyst was analyzed by energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). Electrochemical analysis, including cyclic voltammetry (CV), linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) and potential controlled EHDC tests, was carried out on a Chenhua CHI760e workstation. The catalysts were characterized by H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and H2 temperature programmed chemisorption (H2-TPD) on micrometrics AutoChem II chemisorption analyzer. To verify the involvement of H* in electrocatalytic reaction, DMPO-H signal of H* captured by DMPO was detected by electron spin resonance (ESR) on a Bruker ESR 300E spectrometer. The characterization details are presented in Supporting Information. 2.4 Electrocatalytic hydrodechlorination The electrocatalytic hydrodechlorination (EHDC) of 2,4-DCP was carried out in a double chamber electrolytic polytetrafluoroethylene reactor (each chamber: 100 mL) under magnetic stirring with a speed of 700 rpm. The cathode chamber and the anode chamber are connected by a proton exchange membrane (Nafion 117, DuPont, USA), which is used to prevent the transfer of Cl- (generated during EHDC) from the cathode to the anode chamber. In the three electrodes system, 2 cm × 5 cm sized NF loaded with supported catalyst is used as the working electrode, RuO2/Ti (2 cm × 2.5 cm) as the counter electrode and saturated calomel electrode (SCE) as the reference electrode. Na2SO4 solution (10 mM) was used as the electrolyte solution, and 1 M NaOH was used to adjust the initial pH of the solution to 10. The cathode chamber contains 90 mL of simulated water sample, which is composed of 0.5 mM 2,4-DCP and 10 mM Na2SO4, while the anode chamber contains only 90 mL of 10 mM Na2SO4. Based on previously reported literatures [26–28], 2,4-DCP solution with initial concentrations between 0.1 and 0.5 mM was selected as the simulated wastewater. Before electrocatalytic reaction, ultrapure argon (99.99 %) was bubbled into the electrolyte for 30 min to remove dissolved oxygen and ensure the stability of the reaction system. All reactions were carried out in argon atmosphere at room temperature. During the catalytic reaction, the sample was extracted within a given time interval using a syringe and filtered immediately by passing through a 0.22 µm membrane. The contents of 2,4-DCP, 2-CP, 4-CP and phenol in electrolyte solution were quantitatively detected by HPLC (see the detailed analysis method in SI). The pseudo first-order kinetic model is used to describe the EHDC reaction, which is expressed as follows: (1) ln C t C 0 = − k obs × t Where Ct is the concentration of 2,4-DCP at time t and kobs is the apparent rate constant (min−1) obtained from the linear regression between ln Ct/C0 and t. The mass and area specific activities of the catalysts are expressed as km and ka normalized as Pd mass loading and electrochemically active surface area (ECSA, see Fig. S1) on each electrode, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The SEM images of Pd/AC-200, Pd/CMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300 are shown in Fig. S2. AC has an irregular morphology, while other supports have rod-shaped structure, originating from the special structure of the SBA-15 template [7]. The TEM images of the catalyst and the particle size distribution histogram obtained by counting 100 Pd particles are shown in Fig. 1. According to TEM results, the average Pd particle sizes of the catalysts are calculated using the surface area weighted diameter, and the results are summarized in Table S1. The average particle sizes of Pd particles in Pd/AC-200, Pd/CMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300 are 6.05, 5.34, 4.63, 4.71 and 5.70 nm, respectively. It is noteworthy that the catalysts have similar Pd loadings of 2.0 wt% determined by ICP analysis (see Table S1). Pd/NCMK3–200 displays smaller Pd particles than Pd/CMK3–200 because of the presence of multiple N-containing functionalities in NCMK3, which acts as anchoring sites for cationic Pd and inhibits Pd growth during H2 reduction process [29,30]. The mean Pd particle size of the Pd/NCMK3 catalyst follows an increasing order of Pd/NCMK3–200 < Pd/NCMK3–250 < Pd/NCMK3–300, reflecting metal particle growth with H2 reduction temperature. The microstructure and crystallization characteristics of Pd particles in Pd/NCMK3–200 were also characterized by high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) (results presented in Fig. S3). As shown in Fig. S3a, the Pd particle has a lattice spacing of 0.23 nm in Pd/NCMK3–200, belonging to the Pd (111) crystal plane [31]. The result is consistent with XRD analysis (see Fig. 2a). In addition, the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) diagram of the catalyst shows a clear continuous ring, indicating that the catalyst is composed of polycrystalline Pd particles (Fig. S3b). The STEM-HAADF mapping images show the uniform distribution of N and Pd elements in Pd/NCMK3–200 (Figs. S3c and S4). The electrochemical active areas (ECSAs) and electron transfer capability of Pd/NCMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300 were determined by cyclic voltammetry and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) in order to compare intrinsic electrochemical activity (Figs. S1 and S5) [32]. Although there are slight differences in impedance values, similar ECSAs are obtained on the catalysts in the range of 0.05–0.06 m2 ECSA. Fig. S6 and Fig. 2a show the XRD patterns of Pd/AC-200, Pd/CMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300. Wide peaks at around 23° corresponding to (002) diffraction of graphite carbon (PDF#01–0640) are observed on Pd/AC-200 and Pd/CMK3–200, consisting of short stacks of graphene sheets [33]. Similarly, wide peaks from NCMK3 are identified at slightly higher 2θ on Pd/NCMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300 due to effective N-doping in carbon matrix [34]. The XRD peaks at 40.1°, 46.7° and 68.1° correspond to the (111), (200) and (220) diffractions of Pd (PDF #46–1043). It is noteworthy that the diffraction peaks of metallic Pd from Pd/CMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300 are much weaker than that of Pd/AC-200, largely because of their higher dispersion and confinement effects form mesopores. Additionally, remarkable peak shift to a lower angle is discriminated on Pd/NCMK3–200 as compared to Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300, possibly owning to the existence of a portion of cationic Pd. The surface compositions of the catalysts are analyzed by XPS (Fig. S7). The XPS spectra of the samples in the Pd 3d region are compiled in Fig. 2b and Fig. S8, and the corresponding parameters are listed in Table S2. The peaks at 335.0 eV and 339.4 eV are assigned to the binding energies of Pd0 3d5/2 and Pd0 3d3/2, and the peaks near 336.5 eV and 341.5 eV are assigned to the binding energies of Pd2+ 3d5/2 and Pd2+ 3d3/2, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2b, the XPS peaks of the catalysts in the Pd 3d region are asymmetric and the peak shapes change with catalyst reduction temperature, indicative of the variation of Pd species [35]. To further quantify the contents of Pd species, the XPS profile is deconvoluted, and the fitting parameters are shown in Table S3. In comparison with Pd/AC and Pd/CMK3 with identical reduction treatment, the ratio of Pdn+/Pd0 in Pd/NCMK3–200 is higher (see Fig. S8) largely because of the strong interaction between cationic Pd with N-containing functionality of NCMK3, stabilizing cationic Pdn+ species against H2 reduction [7,36]. For Pd/NCMK3, the content of Pdn+ decreases with reduction temperature. To further verify the conclusion, Pd/NCMK3 with a Pd loading of 10 wt% was prepared and reduced by H2 at 200 °C and 300 °C, respectively. In contrast to the catalyst with low Pd loadings, the 10 %Pd/NCMK3 catalysts display very distinct XPS spectra. Additionally, the XPS spectra of the catalysts in the Pd 3d region clearly show that 10 %Pd/NCMK3–200 has a much higher Pdn+/Pd0 of 1.45 than that of 10 %Pd/NCMK3–300 (0.69, see Fig. S9), confirming the presence of a higher content of Pdn+ in the catalysts reduced at lower temperature. The H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2c. For Pd/NCMK3–200, a small negative peak and wide reduction peak are observed at 80 °C and 230 °C, respectively. Additionally, a very strong and wide inverted peak is clearly identified around 250–600 °C. The negative peak at low temperature is assigned to the desorption of adsorbed H2 on metallic Pd, demonstrating that Pd particles are highly active for H2 activation and adsorption [37]. The wide reduction peaks at 230 °C can be attributed to the reduction of PdOx by H2, reflecting that a portion of PdOX remains in Pd/NCMK3–200 after H2 reduction at 200 °C during catalyst preparation process. The inverted peak at higher temperature is ascribed to the desorption of spillover H on catalyst surface. The very strong peak is largely originated from the small Pd particles with intimate contact with NCMK3, resulting in very strong H2 spillover effects in Pd/NCMK3–200. As for Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300, the larger negative peaks are ascribed to the larger Pd particles, which are apt to the formation of β-PdH phase than in Pd/NCMK3–200. In comparison with Pd/NCMK3–200, the reduction peaks of cationic Pd in Pd/NCMK3–300 are barely observed, reflecting a relatively complete Pd reduction. Accordingly, much weak inverted peaks are identified on Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300, reflecting weak H spillover effects because of the presence of large Pd particles with small perimeters of metal-support interface. The conclusion is also verified by H2-TPD of the samples. The H2-TPD profiles of Pd/NCMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300 are shown in Fig. 2d. The weak H2 desorption peaks around 300–500 °C are attributed to the desorption of adsorbed H2 on metallic Pd particles. In parallel, the strength of H2 desorption peaks around 300–500 °C decreases with reduction temperature. The remarkably weakened H spillover effects confirms the formation of small Pd particles and high Pd dispersion with large metal-support perimeter in Pd/NCMK3–200 as compared with Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300 [38]. 3.2 Electrocatalytic hydrodechlorination of 2,4-DCP on supported Pd catalysts The static adsorption of 2,4-DCP was conducted on the catalysts and the results (Fig. S10) showed that 2,4-DCP adsorption on the catalysts could be excluded. Preliminary EHDC experiments were carried out in Na2SO4 solution containing 0.5 mM 2,4-DCP at a working potential of − 1.1 V. The EHDC performances of Pd catalysts supported on different supports are shown in Fig. 3a and b. After electrocatalytic reaction for 120 min, the concentration of 2,4-DCP barely changes on NCMK3, while 2,4-DCP concentrations continuously decline on supported Pd catalysts, indicating that metal Pd is the essential active site for EHDC of 2,4-DCP. In principle, NCMK3 is inert and Pd particles are highly active for the formation of active H* under the reaction conditions. Hence, potential dechlorination on NCMK3 and Pd particles can be assumed via a direct reaction pathway by electron reduction and indirect pathway by active H* reduction, respectively. The experimental results disclose negligible dechlorination and adsorption on NCMK3 and remarkable conversion of 2,4-DCP on Pd catalysts, manifesting that 2,4-DCP is dominantly dechlorinated on Pd particles via indirect H* reaction pathway without direct electron reduction on support NCMK3. The experimental data are further fitted to reaction kinetic models, indicating that EHDC of 2,4-DCP on the catalysts well follows the pseudo first-order reaction kinetics (see Fig. S11). Hence, the Pd mass normalized kobs (km) is used to define the catalytic activity of the catalyst for comparison and the results are compiled in Table S4. In comparison with other catalysts, Pd/NCMK3–200 exhibits a much higher catalytic activity of 3.37 min−1gpd −1, which is approximately two times as much as that of Pd/AC-200 (0.97 min−1gpd −1) and Pd/CMK-200 (1.32 min−1gpd −1). Considering negligible catalytic activity of NCMK3, the high catalytic activity of Pd/NCMK3–200 is tentatively attributed to its smaller Pd particles and higher Pd dispersion. To achieve more rational comparison with reported results in literatures, the values of turnover numbers (TONs) and mass activity of the catalysts are calculated and the comparison is presented in Table S5. The TON value and mass activity of Pd/NCMK3–200 for EHDC of 2,4-DCP are much higher than those reported in literatures, indicating that Pd/NCMK3–200 can be used as a prominent catalyst for EHDC of chlorinated pollutants in water. To gain deeper insight into the impact of Pd structural properties on electrocatalytic performances of the catalysts, TOF values of the catalysts defined as specific reaction rate constants normalized by exposed Pd sites obtained from TEM analysis were also calculated and the results are presented in Table S4. Again, Pd/NCMK3–200 has a TOF value of 0.33 min−1, higher than Pd/AC-200 and Pd/CMK-200. In principle, the catalytic activity of Pd site relies on its geometric and electronic effects. The TOF value of the catalyst obtained from normalizing the reaction rate by exposed Pd sites excludes the impact of geometric effect (e.g., Pd particle size). As a result, the different TOF values of the catalysts are solely correlated to their electronic effects. Notably, XPS analysis reveals that the Pdn+/Pd ratios of the catalysts display a decreasing trend as Pd/NCMK3–200 > Pd/CMK-200 > Pd/AC-200, which is well consistent with the order of TOF of the catalysts, implying a positive relationship between EHDC activity and cation Pd contents in the Pd/NCMK3. Such distinct and strong dependence of catalytic activity on cation Pd content reflects the crucial role of electronic effects of supported Pd catalyst in 2,4-DCP EHDC. To further verify the effect of Pdn+ on EHDC activity, we modulate the content of Pdn+ in the Pd/NCMK3 catalyst by varying H2 reduction temperatures from 200 °C to 300 °C, and the results are compiled in Fig. 3c and d. As expected, the catalytic activities of the Pd/NCMK3 catalysts differ with reduction temperature and Pd/NCMK3–200 has a very high catalytic activity of 3.37 min−1gpd −1. Specifically, substantial enhancement in catalytic activity can be achieved on Pd/NCMK3–200 by 215 % and on Pd/NCMK3–200 by 40 % as compared with Pd/NCMK3–300. It is interesting to note that at the potential of − 1.0 V Pd/NCMK3–200 also exhibits a higher catalytic activity of 2.37 min−1gpd −1 than Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300 (see Figs. S12 and 3d), reflecting a consistent activity order of the Pd/NCMK3 catalyst at working potentials with different H* generation activities. Accordingly, Alvarez-Montero et al. concluded that the coexistence of Pdn+ and Pd0 in Pd catalyst is very important for the effective hydrodechlorination of chloromethanes, and the presence of cationic Pd enhanced the catalytic activity [22]. The results clearly demonstrate that the electronic effects of supported Pd catalysts play a pivotal role in EHDC of 2,4-DCP. In addition, we found a similar pattern in the EHDC process of diclofenac, which is also a dichloride (Fig. S13). DFT calculations were performed and the results are presented in Fig. 4, the Pdn+/Pd0 model is established by partially replacing palladium atom with PdO [39]. The effect of Pdn+ was evaluated by calculating the adsorption energy and C-Cl bond energy of 2,4-DCP molecules on Pd and PdO. The calculation results show that 2,4-DCP is preferentially adsorbed on the surface of Pd and PdO with benzene ring parallel to the crystal plane. Stronger adsorption of 2,4-DCP is observed on Pd (111) surface than on PdO (−2.555 eV vs −1.939 eV), largely because of the stronger interaction between metallic Pd and benzene ring of 2,4-DCP. In comparison with free state 2,4-DCP, adsorption of 2,4-DCP on the surface of Pd and PdO leads to decreased bond energy and elongated bond length of para- and ortho-C-Cl bonds in 2,4-DCP, demonstrating effective activation of C-Cl bonds upon adsorption on Pd active sites. Notably, the bond lengths of para- and ortho-C-Cl bonds in 2,4-DCP adsorbed on PdO were 1.94 Å and 1.92 Å, respectively, much longer than those on Pd surface, reflecting more effective activation of C-Cl bond on Pdn+ than on metallic Pd. Such effective activation is largely attributed to the bonding effect between cationic Pd and Cl due to the very strong affinity of Pdn+ towards Cl [40]. Accordingly, effective activation of C-Cl on cationic Pd was also observed previously [22]. It is interesting to note that upon 2,4-DCP adsorption on either Pd or PdO, Ebond(ortho-C-Cl) is more negative than Ebond(para-C-Cl), reflecting a more stable ortho-C-Cl bond than para-C-Cl bond of 2,4-DCP after adsorption and activation. Compared with para-C-Cl bond, the higher stability of orthro-C-Cl bond can be ascribed to its restricted activation on the surface of Pd or PdO because of the steric hindrance effects from its ortho-OH group. Accordingly, para-C-Cl bond is preferentially dechlorinated in EHDC of 2,4-DCP. As a result, 2-CP is detected as the sole intermediate product without 4-CP. Consistently, previous studies also demonstrated that the dechlorination of 2,4-DCP predominantly led to the formation of 2-CP due to the steric hindrance effects [41,42]. To verify the conclusion, EHDC of 2-CP and 4-CP with initial concentration of 0.5 mM on Pd/NCMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300 was conducted at the potential of − 1.1 V, and the results are compared in Fig. 5. All catalysts exhibit higher EHDC activities for 4-CP than for 2-CP, demonstrating the strong steric-hindrance effect on the cleavage of C-Cl bond from ortho-substituted hydroxyl group in 2-CP [43,44]. Consistent to the EHDC of 2,4-DCP, Pd/NCMK3–200 demonstrates much higher catalytic activities for the EHDC of 2-CP and 4-CP than Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300, verifying the universal activity trend of the catalysts. Pd/NCMK3–200 has an EHDC activity of 1.4 and 2.2 times as high as Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300 for 2-CP, and 1.0 and 1.3 times for 4-CP. Notably, Pd/NCMK3–200 exhibits an activity of 2.2 and 3.1 times as Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300 for 2,4-DCP, respectively, reflecting a more remarkable enhancement in 2,4-DCP dichlorination. Such enhanced 2,4-DCP dichlorination can be again ascribed to the presence of high concentration of Pdn+ in Pd/NCMK3–200, favoring concerted 2,4-DCP dichlorination. 3.3 Kinetics of 2,4-DCP electrocatalytic dechlorination To study the EHDC kinetics of 2,4-DCP, the reactant (2,4-DCP), possible intermediate products (2-CP and 4-CP) and product (phenol) were quantitatively determined and the carbon balance was carefully monitored during 2,4-DCP EHDC on Pd/NCMK3–200, Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300. As shown in Fig. 6a, b and c, 2-CP is determined to the only intermediate for partial dichlorination and excellent carbon balance is obtained, suggesting that the deep hydrogenation of phenol and the coupling of intermediates are negligible. Notably, EHDC of 2,4-DCP can be implemented through stepwise and concerted pathways as shown in Fig. 6d. Hence, the corresponding rate constants can be further quantified by fitting the experimental data to the reaction kinetics using the following equations [43]: (2) C 2,4 − DCP = C 2,4 − DCP 0 exp ( − ( k 1 + k 3 ) t ) (3) C 2 − CP = k 1 C 2,4 − DCP 0 k 2 − k 1 − k 3 ( exp ( − ( k 1 + k 3 ) t ) − exp ( − k 2 t ) ) (4) C P h enol = k 1 k 2 C 2,4 − DCP 0 k 2 − k 1 − k 3 ( − 1 k 1 + k 3 ( exp ( − ( k 1 + k 3 ) t − 1 ) + 1 k 2 ( exp ( − k 2 t ) − 1 ) ) − k 3 C 2,4 − DCP 0 k 1 + k 3 ( exp − k 1 + k 3 t − 1 ) Where C0 2,4-DCP is the initial concentration of 2,4-DCP, C2,4-DCP, C2-CP and CPhenol are the concentrations of 2,4-DCP, 2-CP and phenol at reaction time t, and k1, k2 and k3 are the rate constants of 2,4-DCP to 2-CP, 2-CP to phenol and 2,4-DCP to phenol, respectively. The resulting fitting parameters are shown in Table 1. Consistently, the rate constants (k1, k2 and k3) of Pd/NCMK3–200 are higher than those of Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300, again confirming the higher EDHC activity of Pd/NCMK3–200. Notably, Pd/NCMK3–200 displays a higher k3/k1 ratio than Pd/NCMK3–250 and Pd/NCMK3–300, reflecting that concerted pathway prevails on Pd/NCMK3–200 as compared with other catalysts. This trend can be well interpreted in terms of Pdn+ content in the catalyst. Given the fact that cationic Pd plays pivotal roles in the activation of C-Cl bond, the higher Pdn+ content in Pd/NCMK3–200 favors the simultaneous activation of both para- and ortho-C-Cl bonds in 2,4-DCP, giving rise to prevailing concerted dechlorination of 2,4-DCP. 3.4 Electrocatalytic dechlorination mechanism The above results show that highly effective EHDC of 2,4-DCP can be achieved on Pd/NCMK3–200 presumably via a H* mediated indirect dechlorination mechanism [23]. Considering the important role of H*ads in EHDC reaction, the evolution of H* on Pd/NCMK3–200 electrode was studied by CV for the first time. The CV curves with starting potentials varying from − 0.8 V to − 1.5 V on Pd/NCMK3–200 electrode are compiled in Fig. 7a. In the absence of 2,4-DCP, oxidation peaks are clearly observed in the potential range of − 0.3 to − 0.7 V and − 0.3–0.0 V, respectively, assigned to the desorption of hydrogen atom H* adsorbed on polycrystalline Pd particles [43,45]. Compared with the potential of H* formation, more negative potential is necessary for the generation of molecular H2 evolved out of Pd surface. To identify the key active species in EHDC, the CV curves of Pd/NCMK3–200 with and without 2,4-DCP in the scanning range of 0.3 to − 1.3 V are compared in Fig. 7b. In comparison with the absence of 2,4-DCP, A1 and A2 peaks are substantially attenuated upon the addition of 2,4-DCP, attributed to effective consumption of H* due to EHDC of 2,4-DCP. The results clearly demonstrate that the adsorbed atomic H* corresponding to A1 and A2 peaks is the key species involved in the electrocatalytic dechlorination reaction. In principle, EHDC reaction on Pd based catalyst is commonly accompanied by hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), both of which are initiated by the Volmer step and formation of atomic H* [46]. To confirm this hypothesis, LSV scans were performed on Pd/NCMK3–200 electrode, and the results are presented in Fig. 7c. The LSV curve without 2,4-DCP does not show any reduction peaks within − 0.3 and − 1.0 V, and the HER current presents at potential below − 1.0 V. Upon 2,4-DCP addition, the increment in reduction peak current is clearly identified about − 0.95 V, proving the involvement of atomic H* in 2,4-DCP EHDC at a potential higher than that of HER reaction. We further carried out EPR study using 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline (DMPO) as the trapping agent to testify the formation of active H* on Pd/NCMK3–200 electrode (results presented in Fig. 7d). Consistently, EPR results shows that 9 characteristic peaks assigned to DMPO-H* adduct are clearly observed, proving the effective generation of H* on Pd/NCMK3–200 electrode [47]. To further evaluate the contribution of atomic H* , 2,4-DCP EHDC on Pd/NCMK3–200 electrode was performed in the presence of t-BuOH, a special scavenger of atomic H* [48]. Fig. 8 shows that without t-BuOH, 2,4-DCP removal is 80.3 % after 120 min reaction at an applied potential of − 1.1 V, while the removals of 2,4-DCP are 66.0 %, 42.5 % and 28.8 % in the presence of 10, 30 and 50 mM t-BuOH, respectively, reflecting that the removal of 2,4-DCP is significantly inhibited with the increase of t-BuOH concentration. The results exclusively demonstrate that the indirect dechlorination pathway based on active H* plays a prevailing role in 2,4-DCP EHDC on Pd/NCMK3–200 electrode. Consistently, similar results are also observed in previous studies [49,50]. The indirect hydrodechlorination process of 2,4-DCP is summarized as shown in Fig. 8c. According to the above results, although the formation of H* is favored at a more negative potential, Pd/NCMK3–200 still showed excellent performance of 2,4-DCP EHDC at - 1.1 V potential. Therefore, H*ads production is not the sole rate determining step of EHDC. Besides the formation of active H* , the EHDC rate is likely correlated to the concentration of 2,4-DCP adsorbed on catalyst surface. Hence, we examined EHDC of 2,4-DCP on Pd/NCMK3–200 with initial concentrations ranging from 0.1 mM to 0.5 mM, and the results are shown in Fig. S14. It is very clear that the EHDC rate is enhanced with initial 2,4-DCP. The initial EHDC kinetics is fitted to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood model, which is widely used to describe the kinetics of heterogeneous catalytic reactions: (5) r 0 = − dC dt = k r K C 0 1 + K C 0 (6) 1 r 0 = 1 k r K × 1 C 0 + 1 k r Where r0 represents the initial reaction rate of 2,4-DCP with an initial concentration of C0, kr and K are the apparent rate constants of surface reaction (mg L−1min−1) and the adsorption equilibrium constant (L mg−1), respectively. As shown in Fig. S14b, a very good linear relationship between 1/r0 and 1/C0 (R2 = 0.99) is achieved, reflecting that the EHDC rate is determined by the conversion of 2,4-DCP adsorbed on catalyst surface. 3.5 Effect of experimental conditions and durability The effect of working potential on the EHDC performance of Pd/NCMK3–200 was explored, and the results are compiled in Figs. S15 and S16. The activity of the catalyst first increases with working potential to − 1.2 V, and then decreases with working potential further increasing to − 1.3 V, reflecting a volcanic shape dependency of catalytic activity on working potential. The enhanced activity can be ascribed to the elevated H* production with the potential [41,51]. Further increase of the potential to − 1.3 V leads to the decline of catalytic activity, likely due to the enhanced competition from hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and strengthened electrostatic field, impeding EHDC of 2,4-DCP by preventing the adsorption of negatively charged reactants and intermediates on electrode surface [52]. The results are consistent with the above kinetic calculation results. The value of k3/k1 also shows the change of volcanic shape with the potential, which proves the important contribution of electronic effect in the EHDC process (see Table 1). In addition, the influence of initial pH on the electrocatalytic hydrogenation dechlorination activity was explored (Fig. S17). Despite favoring H* formation, acidic reaction condition is also prone to inducing competitive HER process. As a result, the catalyst exhibits lower mass activities of 2.92 and 3.05 min−1 gpd −1 at acidic pH of 3 and 6, respectively, suggesting that sufficient H * is generated even under alkaline pH in the EHDC process [41,49,53,54]. In the practical application of electrocatalysis, the stability of the electrode catalyst plays a crucial role in the electrocatalytic removal of pollutants. To investigate the stability of catalyst, five consecutive recycling experiment of 2,4-DCP EHDC was carried out at − 1.1 V on Pd/NCMK3–200 and the results are shown in Fig. 9. In each cycle, similar 2,4-DCP removals are achieved varying from 82 % to 88 %, and no distinct decline in catalytic activity is observed during catalyst recycling, indicating that Pd/NCMK3–200 has good reusability. The catalyst used for 5 cycles was further characterized using SEM, TEM, XPS and ICP analysis and the results are presented in Fig. S2, Fig. S18, Fig. S8 and Table S1. Fig. S18 shows the morphology of Pd/NCMK3–200 after cycling. Pd particles are slightly changed, and the average particle size is counted to be 5.02 nm. The XPS analysis (see Table S3) indicates that the Pd2+/Pd0 ratio of the used Pd/NCMK3–200 is 1.44, nearly identical to that of the fresh catalyst Pd/NCMK3–200 with a Pd2+/Pd0 ratio of 1.56. Similarly, ICP data shows that the Pd loading of used catalyst is 2.1 wt%, approximately equal to that of the fresh catalyst. Hence, the high stability of Pd/NCMK3–200 can be attributed to the presence of N-containing functionality with very strong metal support interaction with Pd particles, which stabilizes the electronic structure of Pd particles and suppress the loss of metal particles [36]. The results clearly demonstrate that the highly stable Pd/NCMK3–200 can be utilized as a prominent catalyst in electrocatalytic dehalogenation of halogenated organic pollutants. 4 Conclusion The electrocatalytic performances of noble metal catalysts are strongly dependent on their geometric and electronic effects. However, few studies addressing the influence of electronic effects on electrocatalytic hydrodechlorination. In the present study, we prepared Pd catalysts supported on AC, CMK3 and NCMK3, and electrocatalytic hydrodechlorination of 2,4-DCP was performed on the catalysts. The electronic properties of the Pd/NCMK-3 catalysts were tuned via varying reduction temperatures. The results show that Pd/NCMK-3 has a much higher catalytic activity than other catalysts due to its higher Pd dispersion. Additionally, a higher TOF value is obtained on Pd/NCMK-3, attributed to its higher Pdn+ content. The electronic properties of Pd particles in Pd/NCMK-3 are further modulated at different H2 reduction temperatures. Characterization results demonstrate that Pdn+ content decreases with reduction temperature. Consistently, Pd/NCMK-3–200 exhibits a higher EHDC activity than those catalysts reduced at higher temperatures, confirming the pivotal role of Pdn+. The DFT calculation discloses that more effective activation of C-Cl bonds of 2,4-DCP can be achieved on Pd-PdO surface than on metallic Pd. The kinetics analysis demonstrates that EHDC of 2,4-DCP on the Pd/NCMK3 catalysts is accomplished via both stepwise and concerted pathways, and the concerted pathway prevails on Pd/NCMK-3–200 due to its higher Pdn+ content. Mechanism study reveals that H* can be formed on electrode surface, and play a crucial role in EHDC of 2,4-DCP, reflecting an indirect dechlorination pathway. Furthermore, Pd/NCMK-3–200 exhibits a very high catalytic stability, highlighting that the catalyst can be used as a promising catalyst in electrocatalytic dechlorination of chlorinated organic pollutants. coredata.dc:description: The Pd catalysts supported on activated carbon (AC), ordered mesoporous carbon (CMK3) and N-doped mesoporous carbon (NCMK3) were prepared, and electrocatalytic hydrodechlorination (EHDC) of 2,4-dichlorophenol (2,4-DCP) was studied on the catalysts. The electronic properties of Pd particles in Pd/NCMK3 were modulated using varied reduction temperature. Increasing reduction temperature from 200 to 300 °C leads to the decrease of Pdn+/Pd0 in Pd/NCMK3 from 1.56 to 0.83. As a result, Pd/NCMK3 reduced at 200 °C exhibits substantially enhanced EHDC activity for 2,4-DCP with a peak mass activity of 3.37 min−1 mgPd −1, which is much better than previously reported catalysts. The DFT calculation shows that highly effective activation of C-Cl bonds can be achieved on cationic Pd species. Furthermore, the Pd/NCMK3 catalyst shows excellent electrocatalytic stability for EHDC of 2,4-DCP, demonstrating its great potential in the long-term application in the electrocatalytic removal of chlorinated pollutants.
coredata.dc:title: Electrocatalytic hydrodechlorination of 2,4-dichlorophenol on Pd catalysts supported on N-doped mesoporous carbons: Impact of electronic effects
